page.title: 06GEOGRAPHY AND ENVIROMENT
page.content: The unique character of this area is derived from it's outstanding natural beauty and the wealth of buildings of architectural interest interacting. The hills are of solid chalk, often containing intriging marine fossils. In one or two places the chalk gives way to patches of reddish brown soil, with flints of up to 30cm dia. making ploughing difficult. The flat tops of the hills are used for arable farming, but sheep and grazing occupy the majority of the land. In the past there were large estates with parkland. The evidence of this is the many mature Oak and Beech trees that the cows now graze under. The River Nailbourne rises in Lyminge and flows through the valley. There is still evidence of the Elham valley railway, which ran closely parallel to the stream.
